concepts.concept_name: Types of nutrients and their functions
Types of teeth and dental care

in_scope: Nutrients: carbohydrates (energy), proteins (growth and repair), fats (energy storage and warmth)
Vitamins and minerals: protect from diseases, keep body healthy
Water and roughage: importance in diet
Sources of nutrients in common Indian foods (rice, dal, roti, milk, fruits, vegetables)
Balanced diet: eating all food groups in right amounts
Food pyramid basics
Digestion starts in mouth with chewing and saliva
Food pipe (oesophagus) carries food to stomach
Stomach churns food and mixes with digestive juices
Small intestine absorbs nutrients into blood
Large intestine absorbs water, waste removed from body
Four types of teeth: incisors (cutting), canines (tearing), premolars and molars (grinding)
Milk teeth and permanent teeth
Dental care: brushing twice daily, avoiding too many sweets
out_of_scope: Basic food groups only - Covered in Class 1-2
Enzymes and chemical digestion - Introduced in Class 7
Detailed nutrient chemistry - Introduced in Class 8
Deficiency diseases in detail - Introduced in Class 6

concepts.concept_name: Parts of a flower and their functions

in_scope: Photosynthesis: plants make food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide
Chlorophyll in leaves gives green colour and helps make food
Leaves take in carbon dioxide and give out oxygen
Parts of a flower: sepals, petals, stamens (male), pistil (female)
Stamen has anther (makes pollen) and filament
Pistil has stigma, style, and ovary
Pollination: transfer of pollen from anther to stigma
Self-pollination and cross-pollination
Agents of pollination: wind, water, insects, birds
After pollination, ovary becomes fruit, ovule becomes seed
Seed dispersal by wind (dandelion, maple), water (coconut), animals (berry), explosion (balsam)
Why seed dispersal is important: avoid overcrowding
out_of_scope: Basic plant parts only - Covered in Class 1-2
Chemical equation of photosynthesis - Introduced in Class 7
Fertilization process in detail - Introduced in Class 7
Vegetative propagation - Introduced in Class 7

in_scope: Vertebrates: animals with backbone; invertebrates: animals without backbone
Mammals: warm-blooded, have hair/fur, give birth to babies, feed milk (cow, dog, whale)
Birds: have feathers, lay eggs, most can fly (parrot, eagle, penguin)
Reptiles: cold-blooded, have scales, lay eggs (snake, lizard, crocodile)
Amphibians: live on land and water, moist skin (frog, toad, salamander)
Fish: live in water, have fins and scales, breathe through gills
Insects: six legs, three body parts (head, thorax, abdomen), most have wings
Common insects: butterfly, ant, bee, mosquito, grasshopper
Life cycle of butterfly: egg - caterpillar (larva) - pupa (chrysalis) - adult butterfly
Life cycle of frog: egg - tadpole - froglet - adult frog
Metamorphosis: complete change in body form during growth
out_of_scope: Basic animal types only - Covered in Class 1-2
Detailed classification with phyla - Introduced in Class 7
Reproduction in animals - Introduced in Class 8
Animal cell structure - Introduced in Class 6

in_scope: Skeleton gives shape, supports body, protects internal organs
Major bones: skull (protects brain), rib cage (protects heart and lungs), spine/backbone (support)
Backbone made of small bones called vertebrae
Limb bones: arm bones (humerus), leg bones (femur)
Joints: places where two bones meet
Types of joints: hinge joint (knee, elbow), ball-and-socket joint (shoulder, hip), pivot joint (neck)
Fixed joints in the skull
Muscles attached to bones help us move
Muscles work in pairs: one contracts while the other relaxes
Types of teeth: incisors, canines, premolars, molars
Milk teeth fall and are replaced by permanent teeth
Good posture: sitting straight, carrying school bag properly
Exercise and calcium-rich food for strong bones and muscles
out_of_scope: Basic body parts only - Covered in Class 1-2
Detailed bone anatomy - Introduced in Class 6-7
Muscle tissue types (voluntary, involuntary, cardiac) - Introduced in Class 7
Skeletal disorders - Introduced in Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Properties of solids, liquids, and gases

in_scope: Three states of matter: solid, liquid, gas
Solids have definite shape and definite volume (book, stone, chair)
Liquids have no definite shape but definite volume (water, milk, juice)
Liquids take the shape of their container
Gases have no definite shape and no definite volume (air, steam, cooking gas)
Gases fill up the entire space available
Melting: solid to liquid (ice to water)
Freezing: liquid to solid (water to ice)
Evaporation: liquid to gas (water drying from clothes)
Condensation: gas to liquid (water drops on cold glass)
Common materials: wood, metal, plastic, glass, rubber, cloth
Properties of materials: hard/soft, rough/smooth, transparent/opaque
Natural materials (wood, cotton, wool) vs man-made materials (plastic, nylon, glass)
out_of_scope: Living and non-living things only - Covered in Class 2
Particle theory of matter - Introduced in Class 6
Physical and chemical changes - Introduced in Class 7
Atoms and molecules - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Force is a push or a pull
A force can start motion, stop motion, change speed, change direction, change shape
Muscular force: force applied by muscles (pushing, pulling, lifting)
Gravitational force (gravity): pulls objects toward Earth
Frictional force: slows down or stops moving objects
Magnetic force: magnets attract iron objects
Forms of energy: heat energy, light energy, sound energy, electrical energy
Sun is the main source of energy
Food gives us energy to work and play
Simple machines make work easier: lever (see-saw), inclined plane (ramp), pulley (well), wheel and axle (door knob)
Examples of simple machines in daily life
out_of_scope: Basic push and pull only - Covered in Class 1-2
Force measurement and units - Introduced in Class 6
Work and energy calculations - Introduced in Class 8
Conservation of energy - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Weather: condition of air at a place at a given time
Weather elements: temperature (hot/cold), rainfall, wind, humidity, clouds
Weather can change from day to day
Seasons in India: summer (March-May), rainy/monsoon (June-September), autumn (October-November), winter (December-February), spring (February-March)
Summer: hot, people wear cotton clothes, drink cold water, eat ice cream
Rainy season: wet, use umbrella and raincoat, puddles form
Winter: cold, people wear woollen clothes, drink hot soup
Water cycle: evaporation (water to vapour), condensation (vapour to clouds), precipitation (rain/snow)
Sun heats water in rivers, oceans; water evaporates
Water vapour rises, cools, forms clouds
Clouds release water as rain or snow
Rain fills rivers, lakes, and goes into the ground
Weather affects clothes we wear, food we eat, activities we do
out_of_scope: Basic seasons identification only - Covered in Class 1-2
Climate zones and types - Introduced in Class 6
Weather instruments in detail - Introduced in Class 7
Climate change and global warming - Introduced in Class 7

in_scope: Soil: top layer of Earth's surface where plants grow
Types of soil: sandy soil (loose, drains water fast), clayey soil (sticky, holds water), loamy soil (best for plants, mix of sand, clay, humus)
Humus: decayed remains of plants and animals in soil
Soil is important for growing plants and crops
Rocks: hard, solid materials found on Earth
Rocks can be big (mountains) or small (pebbles)
Minerals: natural substances found in rocks (iron, gold, diamond, salt)
Uses of minerals: iron for building, salt for cooking, gold for jewellery
Natural resources: things from nature that we use (water, air, soil, minerals, forests)
Renewable resources: can be replaced (water, forests, sunlight)
Non-renewable resources: cannot be replaced easily (coal, oil, minerals)
Conservation: saving and protecting natural resources
Ways to conserve: save water, plant trees, reduce waste, avoid pollution
out_of_scope: Basic nature observation only - Covered in Class 1-2
Soil profile and horizons - Introduced in Class 7
Types of rocks (igneous, sedimentary, metamorphic) - Introduced in Class 7
Mining and extraction processes - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: India has 28 states and 8 union territories
Capital of India is New Delhi; each state has its own capital
Difference between a state and a union territory
Himalayas: highest mountain range in the world, in the north of India
Northern Plains: flat fertile lands formed by rivers like Ganga, Yamuna, Brahmaputra
Thar Desert: hot sandy desert in western Rajasthan
Deccan Plateau: raised flat area in southern India
Major rivers: Ganga (longest), Yamuna, Brahmaputra, Godavari, Krishna, Narmada, Kaveri
Rivers flowing into Bay of Bengal vs Arabian Sea
India surrounded by Arabian Sea (west), Bay of Bengal (east), Indian Ocean (south)
India is a peninsula: water on three sides
Neighbouring countries: Pakistan, China, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Sri Lanka (across sea)
Two island groups: Andaman and Nicobar (Bay of Bengal), Lakshadweep (Arabian Sea)
Largest state by area: Rajasthan; smallest: Goa; most populous: Uttar Pradesh
out_of_scope: Basic directions and landmarks - Covered in Class 1-2
Latitude, longitude, and detailed cartography - Introduced in Class 6
Detailed state politics and governance - Introduced in Class 7
Geological formation of landforms - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Taj Mahal: built by Shah Jahan in Agra, white marble, in memory of Mumtaz Mahal, Seven Wonders
Red Fort (Lal Qila): built by Shah Jahan in Delhi, red sandstone, Independence Day flag hoisting
Qutub Minar: built by Qutub-ud-din Aibak in Delhi, one of tallest brick minarets, 5 storeys, ~73m
Konark Sun Temple: built by King Narasimhadeva I in Odisha, chariot shape, 24 stone wheels, 7 horses
Ajanta Caves: in Maharashtra, rock-cut caves, ancient Buddhist paintings and sculptures, over 2000 years old
All five are UNESCO World Heritage Sites
Heritage: valuable things passed down from the past
Ways to protect monuments: no littering, no writing on walls, following rules
UNESCO World Heritage Sites: internationally recognised important places
out_of_scope: Basic awareness of old buildings - Covered in Class 1-2
Detailed Mughal history and timeline - Introduced in Class 7
Architectural styles and techniques in detail - Introduced in Class 8
Conservation science and restoration methods - Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: India is a democratic country: people choose leaders by voting
Voting age: 18 years and above
Panchayat: local government in villages, headed by Sarpanch
Municipality/Municipal Corporation: local government in cities, headed by Mayor
Local government manages: roads, water supply, garbage collection, streetlights, parks
Public services: Police (100/112), Fire Brigade (101), Ambulance (108)
Other public services: hospitals, schools, post office
Taxes: money people pay to the government
Government uses taxes for roads, schools, hospitals, and public services
GST: tax paid when buying goods and services
112: universal emergency number in India
out_of_scope: Basic community helpers - Covered in Class 1-2
Three tiers of government in detail - Introduced in Class 6
Indian Constitution and fundamental rights - Introduced in Class 7
Election process and political parties - Introduced in Class 8

in_scope: Unity in Diversity: people with different cultures living together as one nation
22 officially recognised languages in the Indian Constitution
Hindi is most widely spoken; English used as additional official language
Different states have different main languages (Tamil, Bengali, Kannada, etc.)
Festivals: Diwali (lights), Holi (colours), Eid, Christmas, Baisakhi, Pongal, Bihu, Onam
Harvest festivals: Baisakhi (Punjab), Pongal (Tamil Nadu), Bihu (Assam), Onam (Kerala)
Traditional clothing: sari, salwar kameez, dhoti/mundu, turban, regional variations
Food diversity: North (roti, dal), South (dosa, idli), West (dhokla, vada pav), East (fish curry, rosogolla)
Food diversity linked to climate, crops, and cultural traditions
Respecting other cultures and traditions is important
out_of_scope: Basic festival awareness - Covered in Class 1-2
History of religions in India - Introduced in Class 6
Detailed linguistic families and script origins - Introduced in Class 7
Sociology of cultural practices - Introduced in Class 9

in_scope: Globe: round model of the Earth; Earth is sphere-shaped
Map: flat drawing of the Earth or a part of it on paper
Globe shows true shape; maps can show details of small areas
7 continents: Asia (largest), Africa, North America, South America, Antarctica (coldest), Europe, Australia (smallest)
India is in Asia
5 oceans: Pacific (largest), Atlantic, Indian, Arctic (smallest), Southern
Indian Ocean named after India
4 main directions: North, South, East, West
Sun rises in East, sets in West
Intermediate directions: NE, NW, SE, SW
Map symbols: blue (water), green (forests), brown (mountains), dots (cities), lines (roads/rivers)
Compass rose: shows directions on a map
Legend/key: explains map symbols
Types of maps: physical, political, road maps
out_of_scope: Basic spatial awareness - Covered in Class 1-2
Latitude, longitude, and grid references - Introduced in Class 6
Map scales and projections - Introduced in Class 7
Topographic maps and GIS - Introduced in Class 9

concepts.concept_name: Children's rights and right to education
Responsibilities at home, school, and community

in_scope: Rights: things every person deserves to have or do
Right to Education (RTE) Act: free education for children aged 6-14
Children's rights: safety, food, health, play, education
UN Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC)
Gender equality: boys and girls have equal rights
Girls have equal right to education, play, and opportunities
Child labour is illegal and violates children's rights
Responsibilities at home: help with chores, respect elders, keep room clean
Responsibilities at school: attend regularly, do homework, follow rules, respect teachers
Responsibilities in community: no littering, follow traffic rules, respect public property, be kind to animals
Rights and responsibilities go together
When everyone follows responsibilities, community becomes better
out_of_scope: Basic good manners and behaviour - Covered in Class 1-2
Fundamental Rights and Duties in the Constitution - Introduced in Class 7
Legal system and courts - Introduced in Class 8
International human rights law - Introduced in Class 9
